fields.reasoning: "This is not a valid Name." is vague and does not provide corrective guidance (e.g., allowed characters or length).
The browser message 'Inclua um "@" no endereço de email. Falta um "@" em "user.com".' clearly explains the issue (missing "@") and how to fix it.
"Subject should be minimum of 6 characters." provides a specific requirement and actionable fix.
"Message is required." clearly indicates the field must be filled, guiding the user to provide content.
The field is optional and no validation error was triggered, so no error suggestion is required.

Required field was not empty ('!'); no validation triggered and no error messaging was expected.
Optional text field with no constraints; input '!' did not trigger validation, so WCAG 3.3.3 does not apply.

Input 'userexample.com' triggered an email-format error. The message 'Inclua um "@" no endereço de email. Falta um "@" em "userexample.com".' clearly identifies the problem and how to fix it (add “@”), providing actionable guidance.
Optional field with no constraints; input '!' did not trigger validation, so no error suggestion is needed.
Required field was not empty ('!'); no validation error was triggered, so 3.3.3 is not applicable.

Input 'userexample.com' triggered native email validation. The message ("Inclua um '@' no endereço de email. Falta um '@' em 'userexample.com'.") clearly explains the issue (missing "@") and how to correct it, satisfying WCAG 3.3.3.
Input 'htp:/example..com' did not trigger validation (plain text field with no constraints), so no error message was expected; WCAG 3.3.3 is not applicable.

Input '!' triggered a linked error message: "Name: First Name is not valid. Valid names contain only letters, numbers, spaces, ', or - characters." This clearly states the problem and how to fix it, and it is programmatically associated via aria-describedby.

Input '!' triggered a linked error message: "Name: Last Name is not valid. Valid names contain only letters, numbers, spaces, ', or - characters." The message specifies allowed characters and is linked via aria-describedby, guiding correction.

Input 'userexample.com' triggered a linked error message: "Email is not valid. Email addresses should follow the format user@domain.com." This provides a clear example format and is programmatically linked.
Input '!' did not trigger any validation or error message; therefore, WCAG 3.3.3 does not apply here.

Input '!' triggered a linked error message: "Website is not valid. Must be a valid URL." While the error is identified and linked, it lacks specific guidance or an example (e.g., https://example.com), so it does not adequately help users correct the input.
Input '!' did not trigger any validation or error message for this field; therefore WCAG 3.3.3 does not apply.
Input 'userexample.com' triggered a visible error (error-msg-email-email). The message explains the issue (missing "@") and how to correct it (include "@"), giving clear, actionable guidance.
Input '1234' did not result in a visible validation error; the error element was hidden and no message was shown, so WCAG 3.3.3 does not apply.
Input '!' did not trigger validation; no error message appeared. Since no error was detected, WCAG 3.3.3 does not apply.
Control is disabled, so no user input or validation occurs; no error messaging is expected.

No mismatch error was shown (alert hidden), so no validation error occurred for this field; WCAG 3.3.3 does not apply.
No user input or validation occurred and no error message was shown, so WCAG 3.3.3 does not apply.
No user input or validation occurred and no error message was shown, so WCAG 3.3.3 does not apply.

Input '1234' did not trigger any validation or error message, so WCAG 3.3.3 does not apply.
